#Text=The Ultimate WordPress Speed Optimization Guide
#Text=WordPress hosting Apr 22, 2020 by Johnny 46 Comments
#Text=130+ performance tips to overcome your WordPress speed addiction.
#Text=Are you a speed addict?
#Text=Are you worried about poor SEO rankings?
#Text=Do you want instant loads for your website, EVEN ON MOBILE?!
#Text=Do you want to save money on server costs?
#Text=Do you want to bedazzle your clients?
#Text=Or are you just some DIY-er looking for new tactics?
#Text=Whatever the reason for your addiction, you‚Äôve come to the right place.
#Text=I‚Äôm not going to judge you.
#Text=Or call you OCD about speed.
#Text=I‚Äôm gonna show you the pro tactics that I cleverly thought up in a time lonnnngggggg before WordPress speed-up was a trend.
#Text=(I‚Äôll also warn you about dumb ones that only waste time.)
#Text=I promise this is the toughest speed-up guide you‚Äôve ever read.

#Text=My journey through WordPress speed addiction
#Text=My addiction for faster load times began in 2007, with Joomla (not WordPress).
#Text=I had a few successful sites growing out of control.
#Text=Many plugins installed, ads, hundreds of comments on many posts (some had thousands).
#Text=Slow frontend and backend.
#Text=It was a pain to update as I‚Äôm possibly the most impatient person in the world.
#Text=I couldn‚Äôt stand it‚Ä¶being a boxer, I could perceive even 100ms difference in load times.
#Text=So what did I do?
#Text=I moved to WordPress around 2008.
#Text=Switched themes like 20 times.
#Text=Then switched my webhosting 3 times.
#Text=Then got a VPS plan.
#Text=Then I got 5 more VPS because the first one sucked.
#Text=Then I taught myself how to manage servers because I got tired of admins not being available when my site went down.
#Text=When I finally got my site stable, then came the theme rebuild.
#Text=I rebuilt my theme from scratch several times.
#Text=Also enlisted some developers and coders with much more experience than myself.
#Text=Then I argued with some of them because I didn‚Äôt trust their logic.
#Text=Sometimes only one of us was right, other times we were both wrong.
#Text=Load times improved but my addiction only got worse.
#Text=The faster things got, the more used to it I became.
#Text=The moment I broke the mythical 1-sec barrier, it only felt like I reached the bottom of a new mountain to climb.
#Text=Now I wanted a sub-500ms site!
#Text=Every developer working with me argued the same thing,
#Text=Why do you want it faster?
#Text=Your site is already fast!
#Text=I knew my site was already faster than others.
#Text=What I couldn‚Äôt understand was why a custom-coded site still needed even half a second to load.
#Text=Anybody working with me needs to understand they‚Äôre dealing with an addict, not a hobbyist.
#Text=Anyway, I found a developer friend who was every bit as willing to explore with me.
#Text=He went the code route.
#Text=I went the server route.
#Text=He rewrote our WP_Query from scratch, completely refactored all our CSS.
#Text=Rebuilt all our custom work to be mobile-first.
#Text=And when I say from scratch‚Ä¶I mean from scratch.
#Text=All the CSS/JS optimization you see nowadays, but done by hand.
#Text=He integrated many of our plugins directly into the theme or rewrote them entirely.
#Text=In the meanwhile, I was screwing with servers.
#Text=I didn‚Äôt like servers but I was the more Linux-capable one between us two.
#Text=So I tested various stacks.
#Text=Screwed around with configurations.
#Text=Turning things on and off.
#Text=Tried different security systems.
#Text=Lucky for me, the server world was already quite evolved in performance-tuning.
#Text=With the help of a few senior admins, I was ‚Äòup to speed‚Äô within 1-2 years.
#Text=We were way ahead of the times.
#Text=I doubled back to WordPress this time.
#Text=Now as a speed architect alongside my developer friend.
#Text=We got even more aggressive, inventing many tactics that are either obsolete today or more conveniently-implemented via plugins.
#Text=It‚Äôs amazing how much we accomplished in a time when WordPress and web servers weren‚Äôt so user-friendly.
#Text=Anything we wanted to do, we had to do it manually or invent it ourselves.
#Text=Today, it seems all WordPress users want more speed.
#Text=It‚Äôs actually a trend now.
#Text=Hahaha.
#Text=It‚Äôs not only Johnny ‚Äúthe speed addict‚Äù harassing developers.
#Text=There‚Äôs speed tests.
#Text=And performance plugins like caching, combining, minification, image compression, etc.
#Text=It seems even the average user is trying to remove bloat and provide the best user experience possible.
#Text=Speed optimization is more important than ever now‚Ä¶
#Text=While we do have faster internet, websites are more bloated than ever.
#Text=Themes and plugins keep getting fancier and loaded with more features.
#Text=The majority of internet visitors are browsing from mobile (with less bandwidth and processing power).
#Text=Google now considers your speed as a ranking signal.
#Text=Facebook ads don‚Äôt convert as well when your site is slow (users just click ‚ÄúBACK‚Äù and keep scrolling).
#Text=Faster websites also make more money!
#Text=No surprise, right?
#Text=Faster websites make more money, rank better, and improve overall user experience!
#Text=Are you a WordPress speed addict (with no life just like me)?
#Text=If yes, then you‚Äôve found my black book of speed-up secrets.
#Text=If you wanted just simple tips, please choose an easier speed optimization guide to follow.
#Text=This guide will make you break up with your developer and pick fights with your server admin.
#Text=I want you to learn, but also have fun.
#Text=I‚Äôve been doing it for many years and come from a much harder time when not so many tools were available.
#Text=Everything I share here is EXACTLY what I recommend to all clients.
#Text=Even the $20k ones.
#Text=Even the developers and agencies who consulted with me to train them and their team.
#Text=They all get exactly what I put below.
#Text=Instead of just bullshit generic advice, I‚Äôve listed many sneaky ones as well.
#Text=Some of them are extremely technical.
#Text=If you don‚Äôt understand my brief explanation for it‚Ä¶you are probably not at the level to attempt it!
#Text=Follow what you can but hire if you need.
#Text=Test carefully.
#Text=I‚Äôve gotten many fancy sites ‚Äì nice graphics, over 1mb size, 100+ requests, to load instantly and well under 500ms.
#Text=I‚Äôm sure you can, too.
#Text=I will give you almost every WordPress speed-up trick that I know!
#Text=üòâ
#Text=Let‚Äôs do it!
#Text=SPEED OPTIMIZATION RULE #1: Always optimize for HUMAN VISITORS!
#Text=(not speed tests)
#Text=Optimize for humans!

#Text=Why Google Pagespeed, Pingdom, and¬†GTmetrix¬†scores don‚Äôt matterHow to optimize for Google Pagespeed, Pingdom, and¬†GTmetrixKeep in mind that mobile is slower, making speed differences more noticeable.
#Text=SKILL:
#Text=BEGINNER ‚Äì can Google and follow instructions.INTERMEDIATE ‚Äì working as WordPress contractor.ADVANCED ‚Äì programmer or server-admin.
#Text=IMPACT:
#Text=LOW ‚Äì maybe 100-200ms difference.
#Text=Possibly unnoticeable.MEDIUM ‚Äì around 500ms difference.HIGH ‚Äì 1 second difference or more.
#Text=1.
#Text=Webhosting optimization
#Text=Your webhosting speed determines how fast it can process code, and how many visitors it can handle.
#Text=Compare your website to a car.
#Text=To make a car go faster, you either A) get a stronger engine and/or B) lighten the weight.
#Text=For websites, the web-server is the ‚Äúengine‚Äù and the code is the‚Äùweight‚Äù.
#Text=The goal is to improve our web-server ‚Äúengine‚Äù while decreasing code ‚Äúweight‚Äù, ok?
#Text=Changing your webhosting is one of the easiest ways to improve speed.
#Text=Those of you on cheap $5/month shared webhosting will benefit the most from moving to a managed hosting service or even your own VPS.
#Text=The difference will be night and day without any site changes.
#Text=Moving from managed hosting to an optimized VPS or dedicated ‚Äúbare metal‚Äù server will be another night-and-day jump.
#Text=The difference isn‚Äôt only speed but also a matter of cost (savings).
#Text=A fast server can handle more visitors than a slow one.
#Text=If your server can handle double the traffic, theoretically the bill can be twice as cheap.
#Text=Not a big deal for a small site but what about a huge ecommerce site with a $1k/month server bill?
#Text=50% cost reduction sounds mighty attractive!
#Text=1.
#Text=Choose nearby datacenter location (BEG, LOW-MED)
#Text=Obviously, you should pick a server location that‚Äôs closest to your visitors.
#Text=Ideally, you don‚Äôt want your DNS ping time more than 100ms from the server to your visitor‚Äôs computer.
#Text=There are many implications depending on your needs.
#Text=Local businesses should get a server as close to their visitors as possible.
#Text=Keep it within 100ms or less, within 50ms is better.
#Text=Check ping times with WonderNetwork.The USA is about 80ms from coast to coast.
#Text=Canada and Mexico are close enough as well.All of Western Europe is only 40-50ms, very close.
#Text=Asia is within 80ms between most countries.India/Pakistan, Australia/NZ, Africa are somewhat isolated.
#Text=Local businesses there need a local datacenter.
#Text=Even Singapore to Australia is borderline ‚Äúfar‚Äù by DNS standards (~150ms).South America can be unreliable infrastructure.
#Text=For that reason, many companies in Central/South America still use US-based datacenters like in California, Texas, or Florida (Miami).
#Text=Luckily, Google Cloud opened up a datacenter in Sao Paolo, Brazil.
#Text=Reliable but pricey.

#Text=If you have worldwide traffic (including Asia/Pacific) and no particular core region, I like USA west coast as perfect location for fast traffic to Europe and Asia.If you have only USA & Europe traffic and no particular core region, I like USA east coast for fast traffic to Europe.
#Text=It‚Äôs also good to have a webhosting company on the same timezone as your core audience.
#Text=That way they can (quickly) support or troubleshoot issues when most of your visitors are awake.
#Text=Those of you thinking a CDN can make up for far server location (that‚Äôs not necessarily true!)
#Text=Those of you hunting for dedicated nodes‚Ä¶the best is TIER-4 datacenter with four 9‚Äôs (99.9999% uptime guarantee).
#Text=But good luck getting those guaranteed!
#Text=Uptime calculator (99.9% uptime means 43min downtime per month)Nearest.host ‚Äì cool site showing nearby server companies.
#Text=2.
#Text=Choose the right website hosting service (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=Shared hosting ($5-30/month) ‚Äì fine for small sites and low traffic up to 100k hits/month.
#Text=No access to server configurations.
#Text=Safe choice is SiteGround, Kinsta, or WP Engine.VPS/cloud hosting ($30-300/month) ‚Äì great for medium sites and traffic up to 30 million hits/month.
#Text=Safe choice is Cloudways or Gridpane, or try a fully managed VPS service.Dedicated (bare metal) server ($200/month & up) ‚Äì great for large sites with TONS of traffic.
#Text=Safe choice is LiquidWeb.Read my webhosting review of many companies.I‚Äôm also biased for my own webhosting service JohnnyVPS.
#Text=Buy the best that you can comfortably afford.
#Text=A small website doesn‚Äôt need much power but it‚Äôs still noticeable when you get a better server and appreciated more than you think.
#Text=Think of a new phone that opens apps just a fraction of a second quicker.
#Text=You really can feel the difference and it improves user experience tremendously.
#Text=Shared webhosting is usually slow because they stuff hundreds of customers/websites onto the same server (maximize profits).

#Text=This increases slowdowns, unexpected crashes or server restarts, security attacks, and your email IP getting marked as spam.Shared hosting environments are also slow because they load many scripts/modules to maximize compatibility for as many users as possible.

#Text=And without dedicated resources, your visitors end up waiting in line while the server is busy handling other websites first.VPS/Dedicated servers are faster because there‚Äôs more resources available per account and your resources are serving only your websites.
#Text=You have more control over your environment, can configure it for your needs.
#Text=VPS/dedicated can be costly or difficult to manage for regular users.

#Text=There are cloud-panel services to help manage it and also fully-managed services where they take care of everything for you.Those unable to handle technical responsibilities of VPS can go for ‚Äúpremium shared hosting‚Äù like Kinsta or WP Engine.
#Text=They don‚Äôt crowd the server as much
#Text=but the performance (while better than regular shared hosting) will be still be far behind a VPS.
#Text=3.
#Text=Choose a high performance web server (INT-ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Use any web server software but Apache.
#Text=The best is NGINX or LiteSpeed, or highly-optimized Apache (rare to find).
#Text=The higher your traffic, the more noticeable the difference.
#Text=NGINX shines at simple sites.
#Text=Just set it and go.
#Text=Not much settings to optimize.
#Text=But once you have a complicated site, NGINX is a mixed bag.
#Text=Some NGINX features aren‚Äôt easy to configure.
#Text=If you have a server-admin to fine-tune, it‚Äôs great but many people don‚Äôt.LiteSpeed has more easy-accessible features than NGINX.
#Text=Like when you need some things cached but not others, or dealing with server-level redirects via htaccess.
#Text=LiteSpeed also has a WordPress cache plugin which NGINX doesn‚Äôt.
#Text=That‚Äôs a HUGE advantage.
#Text=(I personally prefer LiteSpeed.)OpenLiteSpeed is the free community version of LiteSpeed.
#Text=It‚Äôs a great alternative for those wanting the free price of NGINX but the powerful LiteSpeed cache plugin.Some webhosts have the Apache+NGINX hybrid stack.
#Text=I feel those are outdated now and makes for unnecessarily slower/heavier stack.If using Apache, MPM events is best (compared to worker or prefork).Keep your webserver updated.
#Text=Later versions can speed up certain protocols and processes noticeably.
#Text=4.
#Text=Web server configuration (ADV, MED-HIGH)
#Text=Most web servers come with safe/functional configurations right off the bat.
#Text=Adequate for the average small site with little traffic.
#Text=It‚Äôs when you get more traffic and more security attacks, or have more demanding apps that fine-tuning the configurations makes a big difference.
#Text=Timeout ‚Äì 30 to 60 seconds is a safe start.
#Text=You can increase up to 600 or beyond if needed for long processes (import, export, backups).
#Text=Keep in mind that allows poorly-coded processes or hack exploits to run out your server resources.# of child processes allowed ‚Äì depends on the server environment.
#Text=Default should be fine.Concurrent connections allowed ‚Äì anywhere from 1-20k.
#Text=Higher is not necessarily better!
#Text=Keep alive ‚Äì on, off, or LiteSpeed‚Äôs ‚Äúsmart keep-alive‚Äù.
#Text=I think ‚Äúon‚Äù is safer.
#Text=If you have LiteSpeed, the smart keep-alive is awesome!
#Text=Keep alive timeout ‚Äì 3-5 seconds is a safe start.
#Text=Increase if needed.
#Text=How many threads, body/buffer size, workers, clients, etc‚Ä¶.all that you can look up online.
#Text=It depends on your server size and use scenario.
#Text=Jump on forums and ask around or have a sys-admin configure for you.
#Text=Keep in mind different admins have their own ways of configuring.
#Text=The most important distinction for me is to decide whether this server should be set aggressive or conservative:
#Text=AGGRESSIVE configuration ‚Äì gives every site as much resources as possible.
#Text=Good for low-tenant or dedicated servers.CONSERVATIVE configuration ‚Äì gives every site as little resources as possible.
#Text=Good for high-tenant or shared servers.
#Text=5.
#Text=Disable unused services (INT, HIGH)
#Text=Many servers are automatically set up with all features running to make things easy for you.
#Text=But they‚Äôre just like brand new computers with pre-installed software.
#Text=Get rid of the ones you don‚Äôt use.
#Text=Even if they don‚Äôt use much memory, they can still be bombarded by hackers and that eats resources.
#Text=DNS ‚Äì disable if you‚Äôre using external DNS service.
#Text=(Cloudflare, DNSME, etc.)Email ‚Äì disable if you‚Äôre using 3rd-party email.
#Text=(G-Suite, MXroute, etc.)FTP/SFTP ‚Äì disable if not using.Memcache/Redis ‚Äì disable if you don‚Äôt use it.Other services ‚Äì Varnish, Elastipress, etc.
#Text=If you want to be OCD, scan your system for all listening ports and services.
#Text=6.
#Text=Remove unused server modules (ADV, LOW)
#Text=Want to be even more OCD?
#Text=Disable every single module not used by the server.
#Text=Some of them are junk unused server stuff; others are unused Linux distro stuff.
#Text=Old school Apache-compatible stacks or unoptimized control panels tend to have many unused modules enabled by default (while also not enabling ones you might need).
#Text=Read documentation and check online before blindly removing or replacing them.
#Text=The danger is you disable things you need (or worse, one that improves performance).
#Text=You should make a list of disabled services/modules to reference later or give to a contractor when troubleshooting.
#Text=7.
#Text=Use the latest PHP version (INT-ADV, HIGH)
#Text=The PHP version alone makes a HUGE difference.
#Text=Use the latest PHP version possible!
#Text=(Easily-configured from your webhosting control panel.)For example, PHP 7.0 is 3 times faster than PHP 5.6.
#Text=Even PHP 7.3 is 10% faster than PHP 7.2.
#Text=At the time of this writing, PHP 7.4 is available.Be wary of any webhosts still using old PHP!
#Text=Keeping your website PHP version updated is not only for speed but also security.
#Text=The only issue is some themes or plugins may not be compatible with the latest PHP version.
#Text=You‚Äôll know because your site doesn‚Äôt work right, or looks weird.
#Text=So test carefully and keep themes/plugins updated, which helps them stay compatible with the latest PHP.
#Text=8.
#Text=Recommended php.ini configurations (INT, MED):
#Text=Most of you (on shared hosting) won‚Äôt even have access to these settings or know how to set them.
#Text=But nonetheless, here are my recommendations.
#Text=max_execution_time ‚Äì lower (30-60 sec) is better to prevent resources hogs from lagging out the server.
#Text=But you may need higher execution times for long processes like imports, exports, backups.max_input_time ‚Äì lower (60 sec) is better.
#Text=Increase only if you‚Äôre trying to import something that takes forever.max_input_vars ‚Äì set to ‚Äú1000‚Äù, unless some plugins need higher.memory_limit ‚Äì try ‚Äú256M‚Äù to be safe.
#Text=Raise if you have heavy plugins.
#Text=I like to set lower so I‚Äôm notified immediately when there are memory hogs.
#Text=The ‚Äúerror_log‚Äù will tell you if you need more.zlib.output_compression ‚Äì may or may not help.
#Text=I leave it off.
#Text=9.
#Text=Use an updated MySQL fork version (INT-ADV, LOW)
#Text=Most people only know of MySQL, which is now acquired/owned by Oracle.
#Text=There‚Äôs also MariaDB (a fork of MySQL by its original creators) and Percona, and also others.
#Text=MySQL 8 is much better than MySQL 5.7.But it‚Äôs better if you can use MariaDB over MySQL.
#Text=Community-friendly and better performance than vanilla MySQL 5.7.Use the latest MariaDB version that you can.
#Text=Whatever you do, just don‚Äôt use MySQL 5.7.
#Text=What about Percona?
#Text=What about the other 3rd-party MySQL-compatible forks?
#Text=For most sites, it makes little difference if any.
#Text=Don‚Äôt forget to backup your database before changing or upgrading MySQL.
#Text=MySQL vs MariaDB vs Percona
#Text=10.
#Text=Convert MySQL tables from MyISAM to InnoDB (BEG, LOW):

#Text=Make sure your tables are set to InnoDB instead of MyISAM.InnoDB is newer and regarded as being better overall (faster, safer).MyISAM can be faster in some scenarios (when mostly read-only).You can convert manually in phpMyAdmin or use a plugin (Servebolt Optimizer or LiteSpeed Cache).
#Text=Can delete the plugin afterwards if you don‚Äôt need it.
#Text=11.
#Text=Tuning MySQL configurations (ADV, LOW):
#Text=Usually not required (or noticeably-beneficial) for the average site but can help tremendously for large sites with high traffic and varying query lengths.

#Text=You can run MySQLTuner for general recommendations or ask around the sys-admin community to see what everyone else uses.Buffer size, packet size, cache, connections, cache, stack, etc‚Ä¶are all among the general things to tune.Simple Linode guide.
#Text=When trying out random configurations online or copying somebody else‚Äôs, please make sure their environment is similar to yours.
#Text=The main distinctions are:
#Text=server size, resources availablehow many clients/sites on serverhow many end users on serverhow much traffichow big are the siteswhat kind of read/write behavior
#Text=It‚Äôs important to know whether their settings are for efficiency (high-tenant webhost) or aggressive performance (low-tenant webserver).
#Text=12.
#Text=Server full-page caching (ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Full-page caching can help speed-up any website.
#Text=But caching directly from the server is much more powerful and resource-efficient than PHP/application-level caching done through a plugin.
#Text=Some Apache or NGINX servers use Varnish ‚Äì ugghhh, outdated.
#Text=Don‚Äôt use Varnish proxy.

#Text=Just upgrade to pure-LiteSpeed or pure-NGINX stack.LiteSpeed servers can use LiteSpeed cache ‚Äì powerful, many features, and comes with a handy WordPress cache plugin (called ‚ÄúLiteSpeed Cache‚Äù).NGINX servers can use FastCGI ‚Äì great, super fast!
#Text=While there‚Äôs no official NGINX cache plugin for WordPress, there are various ‚ÄúNGINX helper‚Äù plugins to facilitate basic cache functions (like purging).
#Text=To be safe, you should disable caching on pages with forms, carts, or checkouts.
#Text=Private pages (for logged-in users) CAN be cached but don‚Äôt mess with that unless you have that much private traffic and ready to spend hours configuring private cache.
#Text=You can only enable server-level caching if you own or have access to the server.
#Text=Otherwise, your webhost decides what caching options you have.
#Text=Shared hosting usually allows all caching plugins.Managed hosting usually limits you to only their proprietary one.
#Text=13.
#Text=Memory object-caching (ADV, LOW-HIGH)
#Text=Object-caching caches only the database queries instead of the entire page html.

#Text=This technically makes it ‚Äúslower‚Äù than full-page caching (since you‚Äôre not caching the entire page) but useful for speeding up dynamic pages or private pages (logged-in users, admin backend) that can‚Äôt be static-cached.
#Text=Any site with lots of constantly-refreshed data on frontend, or lots of numbers and reports on backend‚Ä¶would stand to benefit from object caching.
#Text=Mostly-static sites or low-traffic sites would not benefit from object-caching at all; don‚Äôt use it on them‚Ä¶it can make them slower!
#Text=Redis is the gold standard in object caching now.

#Text=It‚Äôs superior to the older memcache in almost every way.Memcache is only used in rare situations where Redis doesn‚Äôt work or is slower.If your data doesn‚Äôt change much, you can set longer object caching times (e.g. 60 mins and up).

#Text=Longer times means fewer database queries.Otherwise, stick with the default 5-10 mins to be safe‚Ä¶unless you don‚Äôt mind users seeing stale data.Object caching can be managed by WordPress plugins.
#Text=Most ideal if you have one cache plugin to manage both full-page caching and object caching.
#Text=You can get ~25% faster object caching by using a Unix Socket

#Text=UNIX sockets are run from a lower-level layer on the OSI networking model and therefore faster than standard TCP sockets.Redis and Memcache UNIX socket configuration guides for CentOS.Redis and Memcache UNIX socket configuration guides for Ubuntu.Note: with UNIX socket enabled, only one server user account (and presumably all sites by that user) can use object caching.
#Text=So you can‚Äôt use this if you plan to have multiple server users deploying object cache.
#Text=Some background on memory-caching‚Ä¶
#Text=Memory-caching is the gold standard in caching, because cache runs faster from memory than than from disk.
#Text=The issue is we have limited amounts of memory (most of it already used for applications) so we can‚Äôt store the entire site cache in there.
#Text=It matters less nowadays anyway since server disks are so much faster now (thanks to SSD technology).
#Text=Sure memory is more abundant now too but then again, applications are bigger.
#Text=You may have heard of others loading their entire site into memory‚Ä¶some using the cache route, others by mounting their WordPress directory into memory.
#Text=It works great if your site is small enough but for most people: your memory is only big enough to store database queries, anything else you want to cache will be stored on your disk.
#Text=14.
#Text=Use the latest HTTP protocol (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=HTTP/2 loads browser requests so much faster than HTTP/1 (thanks to parallelization).
#Text=It feels like 3 times faster to me.
#Text=You should be using HTTP/2 or even HTTP/3 (recently released).
#Text=Avoid older web servers still on the archaic HTTP/1.Check your site for HTTP/2 and HTTP/3.Using HTTP/2 requires HTTPS/SSL.
#Text=If your site isn‚Äôt in HTTPS, do it now!
#Text=15.
#Text=Content encoding (INT, HIGH)
#Text=GZIP is so 2016.
#Text=Every web-server should have BROTLI compression nowadays.
#Text=It‚Äôs superior to GZIP (produces smaller files AND in less time).
#Text=But shockingly, BROTLI still isn‚Äôt available on all web-servers.
#Text=If using BROTLI ‚Äì set static compression to 4.If using GZIP ‚Äì set dynamic compression to 1, static compression to 6.
#Text=You can push static compression levels higher if your CPU is strong (or low-usage server) and/or your static content is cached for a long time (long expiry times).
#Text=If you‚Äôre using a CDN or Cloudflare, make sure you enable BROTLI compression there as well.
#Text=16.
#Text=Control-panel (INT, HIGH)
#Text=This issue matters only for VPS users.
#Text=Control panels used to be critiqued for the initial weight they put on the server.
#Text=That‚Äôs because control panels were originally designed for large dedicated servers, but have since been optimized for smaller VPS.
#Text=While it‚Äôs true that having no control panel is lighter than having one, it makes day-to-day tasks harder.
#Text=Their footprint is now negligible considering how useful panels can be.
#Text=The best performing control panel is one that fits your needs.

#Text=Allows you to pick the web server of your choice ‚Äì NGINX or LiteSpeed.Easily configure redirects at server level ‚Äì instead of slower PHP-level redirection plugin.Easily configure granular caching rules ‚Äì choosing what and what not to cache.Easy to manage ‚Äì for you or your sys-admin.Can cage users ‚Äì preventing resource-hogs on high-tenant servers.Secure against hacks ‚Äì as hacking attempts eat many resources.Easy to use ‚Äì for you or your clients.
#Text=17.
#Text=Use external DNS service (INT, LOW)
#Text=Lower DNS latency (small benefit)Easy to update DNS (convenience)
#Text=Will using an external DNS like Cloudflare or DNS Made Easy make a world of difference in terms of webhosting speed?
#Text=I think it improves lookup time but not so noticeable unless your previous DNS server was a piece of junk by cheap webhost.
#Text=The main benefit for me is how quickly I can redirect things.
#Text=Suppose you get hacked and need to redirect through a security proxy.
#Text=Or maybe you‚Äôre switching certain aspects of your site to another server.
#Text=In moments like this, having a DNS service is so convenient.
#Text=You can switch things over with very little downtime, and even switch them back quickly if there‚Äôs an issue.
#Text=DNS services may seem like an extra hassle to setup, but once in place they allow you to integrate new services and mitigate performance issues so much faster.
#Text=18.
#Text=Run WP-cron from your server (BEG, MED)
#Text=Many WordPress tasks need a trigger to function.
#Text=Such as sending out system emails, run backups, release scheduled posts.
#Text=By default, WordPress uses a function called WP-Cron (conveniently located at yourdomain.com/wp-cron.php).
#Text=It works by checking (and executing) for any pending tasks any time someone visits the website.
#Text=It‚Äôs great for small sites, but terrible if you have tons of traffic (triggering many unnecessary cron-checks).
#Text=Also an obvious DDOS vulnerability.
#Text=The sensible thing is to disable WP-cron and use a real cron job whether from your server or an external cron service:

#Text=Disable WP-Cron and use real CRON JOB ‚Äì WPJohnnyThe nightmare that is wp-cron.php ‚Äì The cPanel GuyHow to Disable WP-Cron (wp-cron.php) for Faster Performance ‚Äì KinstaEasyCron (3rd-party service)
#Text=Some cron jobs visit the website directly.
#Text=Others go through the Linux directory.
#Text=Use whichever one works.
#Text=I think a 5-minute interval is good.
#Text=19.
#Text=Caging users & resource limits (ADV, MED-HIGH)
#Text=Do you have many sites or clients on the same machine?
#Text=Are you unable to police them all effectively?
#Text=If you‚Äôre losing control of your tenants, it‚Äôs probably time to limit their resources.
#Text=I‚Äôll start you off with a few tactics below.
#Text=You look up the rest.

#Text=Cloudlinux & CageFS ‚Äì limit CPU and memory usageServer-wide bans on cache-prebuilding, broken-link checkers, and other resource hogs.Decrease php execution time.Global configs blocking the usual offenders, bots, etc.
#Text=Worst-case scenario, just split off some clients onto another server.
#Text=Split them up by size, space usage, traffic amount, whatever you want.
#Text=20.
#Text=Tracking down resource hogs (ADV, MED-HIGH)
#Text=We often run into slow server issues with no obvious clue of where to look.
#Text=Today, it‚Äôs this client.
#Text=Tomorrow, it‚Äôs that client.
#Text=It seems any site can be the culprit on any given day.
#Text=When you have so many clients, and none of them can afford switching plugins on and off, it is really really difficult to track down the problem.
#Text=Here are some ideas:
#Text=Check server logs ‚Äì are you being hacked?
#Text=Are there excessive requests?
#Text=Check server monitors ‚Äì which users are hogging the CPU, memory, and bandwidth?
#Text=Once you know which site it is‚Ä¶check WordPress error log.
#Text=Run Query Monitor.Of course, it might not even happen all the time.
#Text=You have to track down what users or processes were doing when the slowdown happened.
#Text=Sometimes you‚Äôll need more of a developer mentality.
#Text=What plugin was updated last?
#Text=Any new themes or plugins that were custom-coded?
#Text=(Check for memory-exhaustive commands.)
#Text=Yes, you can use applications monitors like New Relic but for me, it‚Äôs overkill.
#Text=The trickiest problems are when it seems like every site is the problem.
#Text=Or also when the server load is low but the sites are still slow.
#Text=Good luck!
#Text=2.
#Text=Theme optimization
#Text=Most slow sites that I see can attribute up to 50% of their slowness to the theme alone.
#Text=Slow themes load way too much junk, offering every fancy effect for every user.
#Text=Imagine a truck with every tool in the trunk, vs loading only the tools you use.
#Text=Sure‚Ä¶many themes advertise themselves as being ‚Äúlightweight‚Äù yet still have way more processing than necessary.
#Text=The worst is when their excessive CSS and JS conflict with other plugins (ecommerce, multi-lingual, sliders, caching, etc).
#Text=Ideally you‚Äôd have a theme that focuses on the design and nothing else.
#Text=It loads styles ASAP so content can quickly paint down the browser.
#Text=No stupid libraries for non-essential items, or endless function checks for user-selected options.
#Text=And you really don‚Äôt want a theme handling heavy functions better left to plugins.

#Text=Sure, these themes with endless ‚Äúextra features‚Äù seem like a convenient 1-stop shop‚Ä¶until you realize they don‚Äôt do as good a job as specialized plugins AND cause conflicts with other plugins.
#Text=21.
#Text=Use a well-coded WordPress theme or framework (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=The lightest and best-coded WordPress theme is the one custom-coded specifically for your use.
#Text=It has only the features you need and nothing else.
#Text=No extra CSS/JS loaded for unused options.
#Text=If coding from scratch, just be careful how you make database queries.

#Text=I like Genesis as the base framework for a custom-coded theme.I like GeneratePress as the base framework for DIY (non-coder) theme.Oxygen Builder is a good visual builder, but meant for developers than DIY.Underscores, Beans, or Roots‚Ä¶are also ok if you know what you‚Äôre doing.For custom layouts that need to be edited easily, use or make a Gutenberg block.
#Text=For all else, make it static. üòâ
#Text=Not everyone can afford a (quality) custom-coded theme.
#Text=If you‚Äôre buying an off-the-shelf theme, I recommend the following:
#Text=GeneratePress ‚Äì using prebuilt styles.Artisan Themes ‚Äì beautiful styles.Stay away from Theme Forest, Envato, Code Canyon.You can also read my theme review page.
#Text=Thinking of any themes I didn‚Äôt mention?
#Text=Check out their support channels and Facebook group.
#Text=What‚Äôs their level of support?
#Text=What type of users are in their community?
#Text=(Beginner or pro?)
#Text=22.
#Text=Tips when custom-coded themes (ADV, HIGH)

#Text=Mobile-first design ‚Äì cleaner code parsing and puts the redraw effort on stronger desktop processors, rather than forcing weaker mobile CPU‚Äôs to repaint.Use WP_Query wisely ‚Äì it‚Äôs powerful, but don‚Äôt abuse your database/memory.Hard-code selectively ‚Äì I like to hardcode menus, headers, footers, and as much of the homepage as possible.
#Text=I let you decide what should be easy to change or not.Clean CSS ‚Äì write it from scratch at the beginning.
#Text=(I think frameworks are too bloated.)
#Text=Grid vs flexbox, Sass or not, choose wisely.
#Text=Refactor it all over time!
#Text=No JS ‚Äì if you can help it, don‚Äôt have any JS.
#Text=(If needed for mobile menu and mobile search, do it cleanly!)
#Text=Choose between CPT or custom Gutenberg blocks.Building functions in theme ‚Äì avoids unnecessary micro-plugins.
#Text=23.
#Text=Clean up your existing theme (BEG, MED)
#Text=Already have a theme and can‚Äôt change it?
#Text=No worries, we‚Äôll look at settings and optimize what we can.

#Text=Disable loading animations/spinners ‚Äì improves perceived load.Disable lazy loading of images ‚Äì improves perceived load.Disable unused features ‚Äì effects, smooth scrolling, Google maps, etc.Combine custom CSS ‚Äì disable all custom CSS enqueued by plugins, and combine into theme custom CSS area.CSS/JS optimizations ‚Äì if your theme has any CSS/JS minification or combination options, enable them!
#Text=If your theme still runs slow, I think it‚Äôs easier to just get another theme and make it look the same.
#Text=You can also recode the theme from scratch and copy the same look as well.
#Text=24.
#Text=JS reduction (ADV, MED)
#Text=I love reducing JS use as much as possible to make themes leaner.
#Text=My common belief is that CSS is for styling, JS is for effects/functions.
#Text=And effects/functions are almost never essential for page load.
#Text=Probably the only essential JS are the ones used for mobile menu, search box, or ATF sliders.
#Text=All other JS are probably non-essential IMO (animations, tab-boxes, pop-ups) unless they‚Äôre loading on every page.
#Text=Convert JS effects to CSS (if possible) ‚Äì this is not only lighter, but can decrease conflicts with plugins.Remove JS dependency from mobile menus ‚Äì try building it in CSS.
#Text=Or even better, just avoid hamburger menus.Disable jquery migrate ‚Äì if you don‚Äôt need it.Combine all JS hacks into one global JS ‚Äì better than having many little JS.

#Text=(Only reason for splitting is if they‚Äôre loading conditionally.)Decide whether you can build all effects with jQuery ‚Äì or dequeue jquery and make your own mini-library.All non-critical JS (if you have any) should be stuck in the footer!
#Text=25.
#Text=Pagebuilder removal (INT-ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Quite often, many sites (lazily) use a bloated pagebuilder to produce custom page layouts.
#Text=But there are 2 better ways:
#Text=Replace pagebuilder using Gutenberg plugins.Hard-code the design and/or create your own Gutenberg blocks!
#Text=I promise you the effort is worth it.
#Text=Just do it and you‚Äôll be so glad later!
#Text=Getting rid of pagebuilders also reduces your number of DOM elements (less work for browsers to process).
#Text=3.
#Text=Plugin optimization
#Text=Plugins can cause up to 50-80% of your site‚Äôs slowness.
#Text=Lean plugins load only the features you use AND make as few and as efficient database queries as possible.
#Text=Bloated plugins do lots of unnecessary processing, make slow queries, and load CSS and JS even on pages not using them.
#Text=The worst plugins add on endless features over the years and never rewrite from scratch, spitting out PHP errors, hogging memory, also creating security vulnerabilities.
#Text=Even better is to know what plugins you really need!
#Text=Just know that plugins usually do either one of two things:
#Text=Give your site a new function (using php/database), and or Give your site a new aesthetic (using CSS/JS effect).
#Text=Do you really need those functions or visual effects?
#Text=Are there plugins that can do the same with less code/bloat?
#Text=And for the plugins you do have, don‚Äôt enable every feature if you can help it.
#Text=Load only what is essential to actually creating conversions.
#Text=26.
#Text=Use only essential (well-coded) plugins (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=There are many guides out there trying to teach what is a ‚Äúgood plugin‚Äù or not.
#Text=Unfortunately, you will only know with time and experience.
#Text=Many plugins advertise similar things and it isn‚Äôt easy for the average user to know which plugins are coded well or not.
#Text=Consumer grade plugins ‚Äì many features and styling options.

#Text=Care more about ease-of-use and having more selling-points, than speed or code quality.Developer grade plugins ‚Äì do essential features really well, include helpful developer functions/filters, and not much built-in styling.Many small specialized plugins can be leaner than one bloated kitchen sink plugin with many features you don‚Äôt use.One big plugin can also be leaner than many small ones with overlapping functions.
#Text=Unfortunately, many people think reading the WordPress repository reviews is enough to know if a plugin is good or not but it‚Äôs sometimes misleading.
#Text=High ratings there might only mean that it‚Äôs popular‚Ä¶doesn‚Äôt necessarily tell you if it‚Äôs popular among respected developers.
#Text=When in doubt, use the plugin with the better reputation among other developers.
#Text=Ask a developer for their opinion!
#Text=The pros ask each other all the time as well.
#Text=We don‚Äôt have time to free trial or read reviews.
#Text=We ask our friends to get quick info.
#Text=27.
#Text=Avoid bloated plugins (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=I don‚Äôt hate all big plugins with many features.
#Text=My problem is with bad coding and unnecessary functions.
#Text=These plugins are on my shitlist for being unnecessarily heavy and slowing sites down.
#Text=I can assure you there are much better alternatives:
#Text=Pagebuilders ‚Äì WPBakery, DIVI, AVADA, Elementor, Beaver Builder.
#Text=All of them are heavy!
#Text=Use Gutenberg blocks instead.Slider Revolution (RevSlider) ‚Äì use Metaslider (lightest) or Smart Slider 3 (full-featured) instead.UberMenu ‚Äì use Max Mega Menu instead if you really need.
#Text=Or custom-code it.
#Text=Or go with plain simple menu.Thrive Comments or Thrive Leads ‚Äì anything made by Thrive.
#Text=I don‚Äôt like Thrive Architect either.Jetpack ‚Äì eww.
#Text=Avoid unless you absolutely need it (like for WooCommerce).

#Text=You can also try Toolbelt which was written to be a cleaner (less spammy) version of Jetpack.ExactMetrics ‚Äì use GAinWP instead (it‚Äôs a fork of the original GADWP)Image lightbox effects ‚Äì try WP Featherlight (yes, it still works).Image galleries ‚Äì try Meow Gallery instead of Envira, NextGEN, FooGallery, etc‚Ä¶or even just default Gutenberg gallery with WP Featherlight.
#Text=Usual plugins suspected of bloat:

#Text=Media plugins ‚Äì anything with lots of fancy image/gallery displays.Anything with visual effects ‚Äì animations or pop-ups, all require JS load.Conditional load logic ‚Äì anything that lets you decide which things and widgets to show on which pages.Font plugins ‚Äì they often add tons of autoloads.Lots of options ‚Äì any plugin with lots of options, or where you enter lots of info.
#Text=How to check for bloat?
#Text=Check website frontend with developer tools and see what CSS/JS it loads.
#Text=Then check Query Monitor for slow queries on frontend, and the database to see if it adds lots of autoloads.
#Text=Should also to check error logs for php errors and also their changelog to see how often it‚Äôs updated.
#Text=28.
#Text=Avoid unnecessary plugins (BEG-ADV, MED)
#Text=These are plugins you don‚Äôt really need.
#Text=There are many other ways to get the same result that don‚Äôt require any plugin at all.
#Text=Yes, I understand some of these plugins will be easier to replace than others.

#Text=Add custom CSS ‚Äì can just put into your theme settings or use the Customizer > Additional CSS.Browser cache or expiry times ‚Äì just use your cache plugin.Font plugins ‚Äì please do that from your theme.Header & footer code injector ‚Äì can put the code directly into your theme files.
#Text=Ask the theme developer if you need help.HTTPS/SSL plugins ‚Äì you don‚Äôt need them at all!

#Text=You can set HTTPS manually.Gallery plugins ‚Äì much cleaner to use Gutenberg blocks and WP Featherlight or my forked WP Featherlight Disabled.Performance plugins ‚Äì simple ones disabling emojis/embed, or doing simple htaccess edits.
#Text=The only performance plugin you need is a cache plugin.Redirection plugins ‚Äì avoid these if you can.
#Text=Don‚Äôt use the redirect functions in your SEO plugin either.
#Text=If your server has .htaccess, use that to do redirects!

#Text=If you need to log 404‚Äôs, just check your Google Search Console.Security plugins ‚Äì many of them only add stuff to your htaccess, which you can do manually.Unused plugins ‚Äì deactivate and or delete!
#Text=Widget conditional load ‚Äì instead of using widget load plugins, you can try creating a new page template in your theme with its own widget position.
#Text=29.
#Text=Prevent plugins from loading globally (INT, MED-HIGH)
#Text=Many plugins load their CSS styles and JS scripts on every page, even when they‚Äôre not being used!
#Text=They do that to make sure it always works but the downside is that it slows down your site.
#Text=Some plugins have an option in the settings to disable global load and/or configure which pages to load on.
#Text=Others can only be disabled with a filter snippet placed in your functions.php file.
#Text=Examples of plugins loading globally:
#Text=Contact Form 7 ‚Äì loads CSS/JS on every page even when they don‚Äôt have a form.

#Text=Sure, there are optimization hacks for CF7 but maybe you can try newer ones like Caldera or WP Fluent Forms.Form security plugins ‚Äì some captcha or forms security plugins may also run unnecessarily on pages that don‚Äôt have forms.Pagebuilders ‚Äì extremely guilty!
#Text=Many load crap on pages not using them, and also for features not being used!
#Text=Slider plugins ‚Äì disable ‚Äúload globally‚Äù option in settings.WooCommerce ‚Äì if you don‚Äôt need it on every page (like non-shopping pages), there are functions.php snippets you can use.
#Text=Some people disable the ajax cart fragments function, too.
#Text=Beware of any plugin that creates its own custom post type or content layout/styling on the frontend.
#Text=Also of any plugin that creates or parses its own shortcodes.
#Text=If you don‚Äôt know which plugins are loading unnecessary, it‚Äôs easy:
#Text=Open up your browser Developer Tools and click on the ‚ÄúNetwork‚Äù tab.

#Text=Then click on the CSS or JS tabs and browse around on your site.You can also load up Query Monitor and browse around on frontend to see if the plugin is making unnecessary queries.Oh and btw, just because you removed a plugin‚Äôs CSS/JS doesn‚Äôt mean you stopped it from loading.
#Text=It still could be running php and DB queries in the background.
#Text=30.
#Text=Dequeue plugin CSS & JS (ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Many plugins load their own CSS and JS which could be easily dequeued/disabled from the plugin and combined into your theme custom CSS/JS (if even needed at all).
#Text=Easy plugins ‚Äì there‚Äôs a box to uncheck for ‚Äúload CSS styles‚Äù from plugin settings.

#Text=If you see JS options, you can disable but check if your plugin still works.Harder plugins ‚Äì you can only dequeue the CSS/JS if the plugin has a filter for developers to put into theme functions.php file.
#Text=After disabling the CSS/JS, you can copy them (if needed) to your theme custom CSS.
#Text=31.
#Text=Clean up wp_option autoloads (ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Many plugins may appear to be ‚Äúlean‚Äù but in fact eat up chunks of memory on every page load!
#Text=They do this by abusing the WP autoload function, which loads data on every page and is intended for only critical data.
#Text=But some plugin developers are jerks, hogging all the memory for themselves like your annoying neighbor hogging all the laundry machines.
#Text=They do it because their bloated plugin won‚Äôt load up quick enough otherwise!
#Text=You‚Äôd be surprised how many unnecessary autoloads are in your database and how big they can get.
#Text=Let‚Äôs find the biggest database memory offenders by cleaning out the autoloads.
#Text=Keep your autoloads below 1mb (good), below 500kb (best).Many old themes/plugins leave crap in database, even when deleted!
#Text=If the name isn‚Äôt obvious what it is, try opening it up and look through the data.When in doubt, search the database entry in Google with its name in quotation marks.
#Text=(e.g.
#Text=‚Äúcherry_fonts_css‚Äù) You can also search the database entry name or plugin name on PluginTests.You‚Äôd be surprised which plugins have lots of autoloads.
#Text=Anything with lots of settings or data saved is suspect, but even small plugins can create giant autoloads.Backup the database before deleting entries!
#Text=Careful about autoloads for existing plugins.
#Text=Check with the developer first before deleting/disabling autoload for active plugins.
#Text=If you want to try anyway (even though I don‚Äôt recommend it), you can edit the autoload option to ‚ÄúNO‚Äù and then delete after a month if you don‚Äôt have any issues.
#Text=Better idea is to get rid of the plugin altogether.
#Text=32.
#Text=Give feedback to plugin developers (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=Quite often, you can complain to the developer directly and they might fix performance issues right away.
#Text=My advice is to tell them how much you love the plugin and just wished they could fix such-and-such so you wouldn‚Äôt have to use a competitor plugin.
#Text=This is much better than a 1-star review of ‚ÄúTHIS PLUGIN SUCKS!‚Äù
#Text=33.
#Text=Custom-code your own plugins (ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Sometimes, the only way is to write some plugins yourself.
#Text=You could also take an existing plugin and chop down from its code, cutting out the stuff you don‚Äôt need.
#Text=If it‚Äôs simple enough, you can also enqueue it into your theme.
#Text=34.
#Text=Don‚Äôt use redirect plugins (INT, MED)
#Text=Try not to do redirects from a plugin (whether redirect plugin or SEO plugin).
#Text=It‚Äôs a bad idea speedwise since php-level redirects are slower than server-level redirects.
#Text=Mind you, it slows down ALL traffic, not only the redirected ones.
#Text=To run redirects from your server, use htaccess (if you have Apache or LiteSpeed) and the proper rewrite rules/directives.
#Text=If you have NGINX, it‚Äôs most likely near impossible unless you have access to server-config and know how to do NGINX configs.

#Text=If you‚Äôre lucky, some NGINX webhosts will have a redirect function in their control panel.Most redirect plugins can export to htaccess rules.If you need to monitor 404‚Äôs, use Google Search Console.If you absolutely need a redirect plugin, use Safe Redirect Manager (not Redirection or YOAST redirect function).
#Text=This is also a good chance to clean out your redirects.
#Text=Get rid of duplicates or redirects for links with no traffic.
#Text=More often than not, I see hundreds of rules that could been more efficiently redirected with just a few clever rewrite directives.
#Text=If you see many 404‚Äôs for Apple touch icons, create them!
#Text=Maybe some of you are concerned about the old saying that Apache is slow because of htaccess (and that you shouldn‚Äôt use it if you can help it).
#Text=Yes, there‚Äôs truth to that.
#Text=But htaccess is still much faster than php-redirects.
#Text=Also, if you‚Äôre on LiteSpeed there‚Äôs no worry at all since LiteSpeed caches htaccess so it has zero impact.
#Text=35.
#Text=Choosing highly-respected plugins (INT, HIGH)
#Text=Aside from choosing well-coded plugins with essential functionality, is to choose plugins with a good reputation.
#Text=Sure you can look up their site and read the sales copy but it‚Äôs better to ask around.
#Text=Ask experienced developers what they use.
#Text=Why they like certain plugins.

#Text=The best plugins typically have the best features (lots of updates), best support, best compatibility with other themes/plugins, best UI (easy-to-use), easy to work with (easily-customizable for developers), scale well (don‚Äôt slow down big sites).
#Text=When I look for a plugin‚Ä¶
#Text=I check the development community.
#Text=I check the WordPress repository reviews.
#Text=I check their development company to see what else they‚Äôve built.
#Text=Respected development companies love showing their success with other themes or plugins, and the people behind them!
#Text=Logical business model.
#Text=One-time fee for small plugins, monthly fee for big plugins, lifetime plan for new plugins, ongoing cost for updates/support.
#Text=The worst plugins aren‚Äôt known by their developer company.
#Text=They‚Äôre on ThemeForest, Code Canyon, Envato, or other crappy stores.
#Text=They showcase the product more so than the company behind it (of course, they don‚Äôt show past failures).
#Text=And their pricing is too cheap.
#Text=Cheaply-priced plugins will get abandoned soon over time and won‚Äôt be updated often.
#Text=Look at their marketing‚Ä¶if it‚Äôs aimed at newbie users, it probably isn‚Äôt the best one.
#Text=4.
#Text=Image optimization
#Text=Images are actually very simple assets, not much complex processing required from web servers.
#Text=Where they hold back your page load is in their delivery across networks and rendering in the user‚Äôs browser.
#Text=Make them too big and they take longer to send and eat up the browser‚Äôs memory.
#Text=More than anything, images affect your website‚Äôs perceived load time.
#Text=Below are my strategies to serving images that not only load fast but keep your website looking just as great as you designed it.
#Text=Please read my MONSTER Guide to WordPress Image Optimization.
#Text=It explains in fuller detail than some abbreviated explanations in this section.
#Text=36.
#Text=Choose proper image format (BEG, MED)

#Text=JPEG¬†‚Äì produces smaller files for photos or images with many colors.PNG¬†(aka ‚Äúpng-8‚Äù) ‚Äì produces smaller files for images with few colors, sharp lines and contrast, and can also do transparency.

#Text=PNG 24¬†‚Äì higher quality version of PNG suitable for photos, but still larger file-size than JPEG, so not recommended unless you need transparency.WEBP¬†‚Äì combines the best of JPEG and PNG, allowing great photo quality and transparency, and better compression than JPEG (smaller filesize).
#Text=Can be used in place of JPEG or PNG 24, but should have fallbacks just in case!
#Text=(FWIW, I don‚Äôt personally use WebP yet.)GIF¬†‚Äì most common in low-quality meme animations.
#Text=Useful when you want to share a video, but don‚Äôt need sharpness or sound.
#Text=GIF is basically an image slideshow format masquerading as low-quality video format.
#Text=Rarely used in a professional setting like a website, where you typically want high-definition images and videos.
#Text=Just know that GIF‚Äôs can be optimized, too.
#Text=37.
#Text=Choose proper image dimensions (BEG, MED)
#Text=Don‚Äôt use a bigger image than you need!
#Text=Resize images to fit the exact area size.

#Text=(e.g. using 400px-width image for a 400px-width area.)To make important or larger images appear better on retina screens, use an image double the area size (e.g. 800px-width image for 400px-width area.)Less important or smaller images can be sized exactly as the area size (no need to be retina-compatible).I believe most people don‚Äôt use retina or ultra-HD monitors in their full resolution.
#Text=Many will scale at 150%, which means you can (probably) get away with only 1.5x image sizes.Don‚Äôt upload raw photos directly from your camera.
#Text=Resize, crop, and edit them first!
#Text=Or use an image compression plugin to automatically optimize uploaded photos.A big waste would be loading a 2000px width image into a 300px width space.
#Text=It wastes server storage, internet bandwidth, and browser processing.
#Text=38.
#Text=Set proper media sizes in theme and plugins (ADV, MED-HIGH)
#Text=Luckily, most themes set the right image sizes already since they control the layouts.
#Text=The issue is more when you have frameworks or plugins using generic media sizes because they don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôll end up using.
#Text=Or you created a new layout that needs a specific media size not already set by your theme.

#Text=Finish your theme design.Then go to WordPress Settings > Media, and set the correct sizes used throughout your site.If you have WooCommerce‚Ä¶check Appearance > Customize > WooCommerce > Product Images.If your theme or plugins create their own image sizes, check their settings and image sizes as well.
#Text=(Some are hardcoded in theme files.)If any media sizes were adjusted or created, please regenerate all your thumbnails.
#Text=What you don‚Äôt want is to have image sizes that don‚Äôt match your layouts.
#Text=For example: your site has only 400px & 800px image sizes, but some image areas are 500px size‚Ä¶it will wastefully use the 800px one!
#Text=The solution in this case is either to adjust the closest media size to 500px or create a whole new media size.
#Text=(Ideally, we want to have as few media sizes as possible to save server space.)
#Text=39.
#Text=Using responsive (adaptive) images for smaller devices (INT, MED)
#Text=Make sure your theme is mobile-adaptive (most themes are) and shows smaller images for smaller devices.
#Text=This feature is default with WordPress and most well-coded themes, and can also be enabled by adaptive image plugins.
#Text=Obviously, it‚Äôs not good to load desktop-size images for mobile devices!
#Text=The problem is that some themes don‚Äôt enable this feature properly.
#Text=Either they load only the desktop-size version for all devices, or even more stupid‚Ä¶they load BOTH (desktop & mobile) sizes for all devices.
#Text=If your site uses large background images, you better make sure this feature is working correctly in mobile!
#Text=40.
#Text=Image compression (BEG-INT, MED)
#Text=Manual JPEG compression ‚Äì use an image editor (e.g.
#Text=Photoshop) to decide the exact quality output you want. 60% for jpeg is safe.
#Text=Can test a few percentage points up or down.
#Text=Good for large or important images.Manual PNG compress ‚Äì use image editor and adjust the number of colors.Automatic compression ‚Äì use a plugin to do it.
#Text=My favorite image compression plugins (in order) are ShortPixel, LiteSpeed Cache, WP Compress.
#Text=You can use these for less important images or non-tech-savvy users.
#Text=Another quick way to manually compress images: just upload to ShortPixel‚Äôs compression tool (free).
#Text=41.
#Text=Convert unnecessary transparent PNG to JPEG (INT, MED)
#Text=I often see large transparent PNG images sitting on a plain white background.
#Text=Eating up tons of space when they could easily be half the size and even look better as JPEG.
#Text=If your transparent PNG sits on a solid background, you can easily convert that image to JPEG and match the color of the background.You‚Äôll save many bytes and won‚Äôt notice any difference!
#Text=If your image is simple, a solid background PNG might still be smaller than transparent PNG.
#Text=42.
#Text=Redraw images or icons in CSS (ADV, LOW)

#Text=Some themes or plugins unnecessarily use image files for very simple graphics (lines, blocks, icons) that could be easily drawn using only CSS.You can check by inspecting visual decorations around your site theme.Redraw them in CSS and you‚Äôll save a few unnecessary HTTP requests.Here‚Äôs a fun collection of 512 pure-CSS icons (by CSS Icon), some even animate!
#Text=Want to be clever?
#Text=You can mix images and CSS together.
#Text=Using CSS to draw shapes in your images or color filters.
#Text=There are so many clever uses that save space and look better.
#Text=Gradients ‚Äì been a part of CSS for a while, especially during web 2.0 era.Shadows ‚Äì use CSS instead of putting edge shadows in your images!
#Text=B&W filter ‚Äì great for reusing an existing color image.Color filter ‚Äì reverse of above.
#Text=43.
#Text=Icon fonts vs SVG‚Äôs (ADV, MED)
#Text=There are many debates in the developer world about whether icons are better as SVG or icon fonts.
#Text=Developers are free to choose because they know which fits their use and workflow.
#Text=Between you and I, here are my guidelines:
#Text=Simple icons (arrows, search glass, hamburger menu) can be drawn with CSS.

#Text=Complex icons (social media icons, carts, notepads, etc) need either SVG or icon font.If you only have 2-3 icons, SVG will be less weight (and can even be inlined).If you have 10 or more icons, use a custom icon font service (Fontastic, Fontello, IcoMoon).

#Text=Or create your own custom font.Self-made icon font (my favorite) and locally-loaded is fastest because even a 2kb small icon-font file can load 10-20 icons, which is all you really need.The hassle with self-made icon fonts is that they take more time to update if you want to add/edit an icon later.The worst icon fonts are the 3rd-party ones loading externally!
#Text=For example, Font Awesome is 30-200kb and loads many unused icons.If using SVG, you can optimize them with Jake Archibald‚Äôs SVGOMG.
#Text=See what you can disable or decrease in quality without affecting appearance.Please don‚Äôt inline SVG‚Äôs unless it‚Äôs really small and only used in one place on the page.
#Text=Most people don‚Äôt have the skills to redraw in CSS or create their own icon font.
#Text=All I ask is that you either use SVG‚Äôs or follow one of those custom font services.
#Text=Whatever you do, please don‚Äôt load FontAwesome as that‚Äôs a good 40-75kb and costs you 100-150ms load time.
#Text=Of course, many theme developers load FA as that‚Äôs the easiest/laziest way to put many icons on a theme.
#Text=44.
#Text=Remove unused media sizes (ADV, LOW)
#Text=Does having a ton of image files really slow down your site?
#Text=Probably not.
#Text=Does it slow down backend site functions?
#Text=Maybe.
#Text=Can it affect your site speed during longer backup times?
#Text=Yes!
#Text=Can it make your webhosting more expensive?
#Text=Yes.
#Text=More than anything, it makes an unnecessary mess out of your website.
#Text=Making it bigger and bulkier than necessary.
#Text=Let‚Äôs clean this up.
#Text=Go to your theme and plugin settings and uncheck/disable any media sizes you don‚Äôt need.
#Text=Some of this work may require a developer to thoroughly check all your page templates, edit functions.php and manually dequeue unused media sizes.
#Text=Having a hard time finding all the media sizes that your site is using?
#Text=A handy trick for me is to install one of those image compression plugins.
#Text=They‚Äôll list all the sizes in one handy place. üòâ
#Text=Get rid of media sizes you don‚Äôt use.Can also remove sizes that are too similar.
#Text=(Keeping the bigger one.)
#Text=Once you‚Äôve deleted unused media sizes, you‚Äôll have to delete the unused images‚Ä¶but be careful!
#Text=There are plugins that say they can do the job.
#Text=Please research and test carefully.
#Text=I‚Äôm honestly unsure of which ones delete only unused media sizes and which ones delete entire unused images.Be very wary of those newspaper/magazine themes that have many image sizes!
#Text=45.
#Text=Using CSS sprites (ADV, LOW)
#Text=Css sprites is an old tactic that actually still works for some use cases.
#Text=A long time ago, some developers used to combine many tiny images into one image file and then call only parts of it within CSS.
#Text=It was a clever way of reducing HTTP requests.
#Text=Nowadays this tactic is isn‚Äôt necessary since HTTP/2 allows you to have many more HTTP requests and most small images can be drawn in CSS, icon fonts and SVG‚Äôs.
#Text=(Design coloring is much flatter as well nowadays, instead of the overly color-esque WEB 1.0 period.)
#Text=You can try CSS sprites if you have many small images that have multiple colors (and/or can‚Äôt be drawn in icon fonts or SVG‚Äôs).
#Text=46.
#Text=Video compression (BEG-INT, MED-HIGH)
#Text=Compress videos as much as possible.Output in webm or mp4 format.
#Text=(I like mp4.)
#Text=Any video that‚Äôs auto-played on page load should absolutely be compressed.
#Text=If you‚Äôre a pro-editor and know how to render the perfect balance between small file-size and good quality, do your thing.
#Text=For everybody else, just do my easy cheat!
#Text=Upload the video to Vimeo, Youtube, Facebook, etc.Then re-download their compressed version.
#Text=These services put out gajillions of videos everyday, I think they got the best algorithms!
#Text=Youtube‚Äôs compression is the best balance of small size and good quality.
#Text=If you want slightly higher quality, try Vimeo.
#Text=If you want smaller size, try Facebook.
#Text=More important than compressing the video, is to decide what you need from it:
#Text=Do you even need the sound?
#Text=(Remove if not.)Do you even need it in color?
#Text=Is the video just a backdrop for text?
#Text=(Can lower quality even more.)Does it even have to be that big?
#Text=Do you even need a video?
#Text=Does it even get watched?

#Text=5.
#Text=Font optimization
#Text=You would think fonts are so small in filesize that they don‚Äôt affect performance, but they totally do.
#Text=Users perceive your website load by your content and the font is what allows your text to load.
#Text=Load the fonts efficiently and users see instant content.

#Text=Do it inefficiently, and users see a lot of blank space (aka FOIT, flash-of-invisible-text)‚Ä¶or worst, ugly unstyled text followed by a screen flash before the font loads (aka FOUT, flash-of-unstyled-text).
#Text=It‚Äôs a really jarring experience.
#Text=Looks like crap and makes your site appear slow (both to users and speed tests).
#Text=Fighting FOIT and FOUT Together ‚Äì CSS-TRICKS
#Text=What makes fonts so slow nowadays is due to the abundance of free fancy fonts (Google fonts).
#Text=Back in the days, you had to pay for fancy fonts so you were much more judicious about their selection.
#Text=Now even a free plugin can load hundreds of Google fonts.
#Text=This makes it tougher to police where fonts are loaded from and for which text.
#Text=Fonts make a visible speed impact no matter how big or small your site.
#Text=And actually, one of my favorite optimization tactics for speeding up already-lightweight sites.
#Text=There are many factors to consider when loading fonts, all of them affecting your content load time noticeably!
#Text=47.
#Text=System font vs locally-loaded vs webfont (BEG-ADV, MED)

#Text=System-fonts ‚Äì faster than locally-loaded fonts or webfonts.Locally-loaded fonts ‚Äì faster than webfonts, and can be CDN/browser-cached.Webfonts ‚Äì slowest, but can load equally fast if already cached.
#Text=System-fonts (already built into the OS) will load faster than webfonts from 3rd-party server (Google webfont, Adobe, Typekit, Typography.com, etc).

#Text=Just know that some system fonts (like Arial, Helvetica) are available on both Windows & Mac, whereas other system fonts are not and must fallback to their similar equivalent (like Segoe UI for Windows, and System UI for OS X).
#Text=I use system fonts for 2 of my sites.
#Text=The rest of them, like most sites today, need a nice webfont to look polished.
#Text=Luckily, webfonts keep improving their load time in various ways.
#Text=They‚Äôre constantly getting lighter and removing unnecessary bytes.
#Text=Webfonts are also cached in browsers so if you‚Äôre using a popular webfont, there‚Äôs a good chance your users won‚Äôt have to re-download it (since they already got it from another site).
#Text=Also, I imagine popular Google webfonts will soon be natively stored in Chrome browser (if they aren‚Äôt already).
#Text=But then again, mobile browsers clear their cache often.
#Text=But then again, there‚Äôs also DNS prefetch which helps webfonts.
#Text=Locally-loaded fonts (meaning ‚Äúlocally‚Äù from your server) is somewhat seen as an outdated way of enqueuing fonts.
#Text=Web designers used to buy fancy fonts from 3rd-party sites, download the whole font family package, then carefully choose and enqueue in the site.
#Text=It was a tedious process and didn‚Äôt let end users (easily) switch fonts in and out.
#Text=But since webfonts are kinda bloated in their deployment, locally-loading fonts is still popular among speed-conscious developers.

#Text=You can locally-load any webfont by copying it to your sever and requesting it locally instead of from a 3rd-party webfont service.This saves a few requests and decreases wait time (with minor and probably unnoticeable drawbacks).Load Google fonts locally¬†‚Äì google-webfonts-helper by Mario RanftlThere are also a handy plugin like OMGF to host Google fonts locally.And tools like Jaime Caballero‚Äôs localFont.
#Text=I personally use only system fonts, or locally-loaded webfonts.
#Text=48.
#Text=Use fewer fonts (BEG, MED)
#Text=Using just 1 font is fastest.If using 2 or 3 fonts, make sure you disable unused styles!
#Text=Having fewer fonts will help, obviously.
#Text=It‚Äôs great if you can get away with just one font.
#Text=It‚Äôs the cleanest look IMO and you can still create different styles by playing with size, weight, letter-spacing, letter case, color, etc.
#Text=But if you need, you can add a second font used for headline only.
#Text=Some really professionally designed sites will even have a 3rd font for subtitles, H3 header, quotes, prices, or other emphasized text areas.
#Text=Some fonts are heavier than others.
#Text=Sometimes, even one font can be heavier than 2 others.Don‚Äôt forget to disable the font load (enqueue) from your site.
#Text=It‚Äôs not enough to simply stop using it.If using more than 2 weights of the same font, you can try using variable fonts.
#Text=They load the same amount of bytes no matter how many weights you have.
#Text=Really cool new font technology.
#Text=49.
#Text=Don‚Äôt enqueue unused font weights, styles, character sets (INT, MED)
#Text=Many people don‚Äôt notice the unused fonts styles loaded on their site!

#Text=I‚Äôve seen many sites loading all the font weights (100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700) and font styles (regular, italic), and character sets (extended latin, greek, cyrillic, etc)‚Ä¶.when in fact they only need font weights 400 (normal) and 700 (bold), and only the basic latin character set.
#Text=Check your site for all unused font styles.Remove their requests from theme and plugin settings.Also remove from header and stylesheets (if manually installed).
#Text=If you don‚Äôt know which ones you‚Äôre actually using, make a list.
#Text=Link to the FOUNT font finder on your browser bookmark bar and identify every font used on your site.
#Text=Test on different page layouts and click on all the content bits.
#Text=Title, nav, headers, content, text in footer and widgets.
#Text=Don‚Äôt forget to check hidden elements like carousel, pop-ups, tabbed or collapsed content.
#Text=Are you feeling overwhelmed?
#Text=That only goes to show that you‚Äôre loading more than you need!

#Text=Body text usually needs regular (400), italics (400), and bold (700)Titles and headings can re-use the regular 400 or 700, but some people want super-skinny (300) or super-heavy (900).Most sites never use italics for titles/headings, so if you‚Äôre loading 900 for them you probably won‚Äôt need italics 900.
#Text=Anyway, most of this is common sense.
#Text=Those of you manually enqueuing fonts are already aware and making sensible choices.
#Text=It‚Äôs the newbies loading fonts through pagebuilders or plugins that are likely having unnecessary weights, styles, and character sets.
#Text=50.
#Text=Font enqueue method (ADV, MED)
#Text=This is IMO an art and massive area of debate within the development world.
#Text=There are many ways to enqueue fonts (especially webfonts), each with their own pros and cons.
#Text=I‚Äôll leave some general guidelines below:

#Text=Fonts should load before the content ‚Äì I don‚Äôt care about FOIT or render-blocking, it‚Äôs better UX to load text in its proper font from the get-go.Font should be (carefully) loaded by the theme, not a plugin.
#Text=If your plugins have font/typography options, choose ‚Äúinherit‚Äù.
#Text=Webfonts load faster when loaded-locally and with long cache expiry times.
#Text=But that speed difference isn‚Äôt as noticeable if you‚Äôre using a common (lightweight) webfont.
#Text=Varvy breakdown on various webfont loading methods.
#Text=The biggest problem with how webfonts are enqueued are due to developers trying to make them user-friendly.

#Text=It‚Äôs when developers try to have endless font-choice dropdowns for newbie users that it gets messy and more stuff is loaded than needed.
#Text=Don‚Äôt get caught up in reading crazy-detailed guides like this or this.
#Text=They‚Äôll spin your head around with all kinds of preload and fallback chatter.
#Text=My bottom line is this‚Ä¶load the font before the text.

#Text=51.
#Text=Automated font subsetting (ADV, MED)
#Text=Font subsetting is an ingenious weight-reduction tactic of loading only the font characters actually used in your content.
#Text=There are many use cases where you don‚Äôt need all the characters in a font.
#Text=For some people, getting rid of unused characters made their font file-sizes 1040x times smaller!
#Text=Only basic latin characters ‚Äì if you don‚Äôt need accent marks, Egyptian symbols and such.Only uppercase ‚Äì title fonts, headings.Only numbers ‚Äì for specific styled numbers?
#Text=Only currency symbols ‚Äì if you use this font only for price menu?
#Text=Only certain characters ‚Äì logos, headlinesOnly common characters ‚Äì all the ones used in 99% of websites.
#Text=Some font subsetting is easily-allowed by webfont services.
#Text=Others, you can only do it manually (but there are helpful tools).
#Text=Below are some tools and guides.

#Text=You can also pick ‚Äúextra characters‚Äù at the bottom.Save page weight with web font subsetting (Benjamin Black) ‚Äì font subsetting from server CLI using fonttools, glyphhanger, and pyftsubset.
#Text=Usually when you do this level of font optimization, your font files get so small that it only makes sense to have them locally-loaded.
#Text=There‚Äôs no point in making multiple calls to Google‚Äôs font server only to get 1/3rd of a font.
#Text=But hey, that‚Äôs your call to make.
#Text=I think if you‚Äôre manually optimizing to this point, just go all the way.

#Text=This ‚Äúlocally-loaded subsetted-webfont‚Äù method gives me nice fonts AND lightweight ultra-fast load.Yes, I lose out on the benefit of them already being cached from other websites or easily updated via font-hosting service.But likewise, they are much lighter and can also be cached in CDN and browser at my specified intervals.
#Text=(Also appears faster in page tests as well.)
#Text=Overall, benefits outweigh any drawbacks.I recommend using only WOFF2 as it‚Äôs the most compressed/lightweight and suits all modern browsers.
#Text=Sometimes, font services load WOFF which is bigger but compatible with really old browsers (not important to me).
#Text=Font-subsetting can also open up creative design flexibility.

#Text=Or maybe you just want a really unique ‚Äú&‚Äù sign or unique letter because that‚Äôs your customized logo letter.
#Text=In case you‚Äôre already doing that, at least now you know how it‚Äôs done without loading entire fonts.

#Text=Avoid duplicate font calls (BEG, MED)
